de.uni.bamberg.wiai.minf.forflow.datagenerator.model.datastructure
Class MetaAttribute

java.lang.Object
  de.uni.bamberg.wiai.minf.forflow.datagenerator.model.datastructure.MetaAttribute

public class MetaAttribute
extends java.lang.Object

MetaAttribute represents an Ecore's EAttribute and can also be called a MetaFacet. This class is part of MetaClass objects. A meta attribute is called meta because it describes attributes and is a model for those. It can hold and specify much more than an ordinary attribute ever could. The following holds for every attribute object:

  • it has a name
  • a data type specifies the data it represents
  • a flag null values allowed?
  • a flag for multiplicity values. It means, is it possible to generate more than one value. As an example the facet author helps getting the picutre. For a document it should be possible to have more than one creator.
  • there's a flag for restricted values. It indicates that not all values should be allowed. For a lot of facets this is true. A simple example is file type. A file type for a document is usually restricted to a handful. Imagine writing a word doc. Legal values are:
    • docx Word 2007 documents
    • doc for Word 1997-2003 documents used
    • txt ordinary plain text
    • rtf rich text format
    • dotx Word 2007 templates
    • wps to load & save Works documents
  • Sometimes the value of an attribute depends on other attributes. In this case we say it exists a dependency. To get a legal value for this attribute all other attributes it depends on must exist, available and previously generated.
  • To get to know how the value or values should be generated a fill type is available. Here testers can specify where get data to that attribute. That could be a file. That is highly useful and helpy when it's a restricted attribute. Other ways are to generated random value when constraints say yes.
  • Of course there's a parameter to store the generated values to this attribute. It's the facet value.
  • Most facets or attributes should have attached an unit to get the data information more precisely. And it helps to get rid off of confusions. A major problem is to specify all of possible unit data, but the system is shipped with a bunch of the most general. And, of course, feel free to extend it and adapt it to your needs.
  • A few points above, we talked about dependencies. If it is enabled with the corresponding flag, you have to define to with attributes it depends. This field is non-trivial and is a very complicated subject, actually. That means, it's possible that, at that state, your needs are not covered, yet.

Since:
Apr/07/09
Version:
0.1
Author:
Michael Munz

setValues

public void setValues(java.util.List<java.lang.Object> values)
sets the values for an attribute. That are the concrete values for an attribute, when it comes to data generation.

Values specified here, occur later in generated test data.

Parameters:
values - list of values

addValue

public void addValue(java.lang.Object ob)
adds an value to the attribute. All values which are added here, are later in generated test data sets.

Parameters:
ob - it's an Object, to be as generic as possible. Because if we specify a particular data type her, it would be limited to a subset. And that's not what we want.

getPreviewValue

public final java.lang.String getPreviewValue()
this gets a preview of the data generation values. It helps the tester to get a clue of the data that is gonna be generated for that attribute and the system gives a feedback that it does the right kind of things, according to its settings.

Returns:
preview of the data to generate

setUpperBound

public void setUpperBound(int upperBound)
sets the upper bound of possible values for an attribute. The default value is set to '1' meaning the upper bound of this attribute is at most one. If you specify it by any other number, it means the possible amount of values is limited to that number.

Parameters:
upperBound - set upper bound of values for this attribute.

getUpperBound

public final int getUpperBound()
gets the upper bound for values of an attribute.

Returns:
integer

isMultiplicityAllowed

public void isMultiplicityAllowed(boolean allowed)
flag, indicating whether multiple values for this attribute are allowed or not. This setting has direct impact to getUpperBound(). In default setting it's not allowed to have multiple values and therefore the upper bound is 1.

But if you set this to true, you have to specify the upper bound by yourself.

For clarity we give an example:

Suppose you've got an attribute (facet) author. Because for an object, say book, more than one author might be involved it has to be reflected in the test data too.

Parameters:
allowed - does this attribute got more than one value?

isMultiplicityAllowed

public final boolean isMultiplicityAllowed()
returns the flag, indicating multiplicity status for this attribute. When true is returned, the upper bound of this attribute tells, how many values to generate.

Default is set to false.

Returns:
default is false

isNullValueAllowed

public void isNullValueAllowed(boolean allowed)
states whether NULL values are allowed for this kind of attribute. Null values have the effect that it is possible to skip generation of any data for this attribute and leave it as it is, when it comes to test data generation.

Default value is set to 'false'.

Parameters:
allowed - do you wanna allow the generation of null values for this kind of attribute?

isNullValueAllowed

public final boolean isNullValueAllowed()
gets the NULL value flag.

Default value is set to false.

Returns:
true, if null values are allowed for this attribute

setPercentOfNullValues

public void setPercentOfNullValues(int percent)
If Null values are allowed, then the amount of null values has to be specified by the tester.

Parameters:
percent - amount of null values in percent.

getPercentOfNullVallues

public final int getPercentOfNullVallues()
If Null values are allowed, then the amount of null values has to be specified by the tester. As default value 0 is set. This means, no data set of this attribute has any null value.

Example:
when 10 has been returned it means 10 percent of the values should be null

Returns:
amount of null values in percent

isValueRestricted

public void isValueRestricted(boolean restricted)
set whether values are restricted or not. Attributes with this flag enabled are only allowed to have a subset of possible values. In real life data most attributes will have this parameter enabled.

Parameters:
restricted - enables or disables restriction

isValueRestricted

public final boolean isValueRestricted()
indicates the restriction setting. Restricted attributes can have only pre-defined values, when generation is done. It is not allowed to have any values not defined.

Default value is se to false.

Returns:
restriction setting enabled or disabled

existsDependency

public void existsDependency(boolean dependency)
sets the setting to handle dependencies. Enable this setting to any attribute which depends on a value of another attribute.

If this is enabled one has to specify the attributes it depends on.

Parameters:
dependency - sets the dependency setting

exitsDependency

public final boolean exitsDependency()
tells if dependencies are exist or not to this attribute. In most cases it can be ignored, because there are no dependencies between attributes.

Default is set to false.

Returns:
true, if dependency exits

setDependencies

public void setDependencies(java.util.List<Dependency> dependencies)
sets the attributes this one depends upon. The attributes listed here must computed first before any dependent attribute is considered.

Parameters:
dependencies - list of attributes this one depends upon.

addDependency

public void addDependency(Dependency dependency)
adds an attribute to the list to consider first.

Parameters:
dependency - a new attribute this one depends.

getDependencies

public final java.util.List<Dependency> getDependencies()
gets all attributes this one depends. The list will only return elements, if and only if exitsDependency() is enabled.

Returns:
list of attributes this one depends or null

setFillType

public void setFillType(FillType fillType)
specifies the type of filling. In other words, it defines the way test data is gonna be generated for this attribute. There are a different types possible, for example by linking to an external file, by a pre-defined generator, by an interval or even by a formula.

There are more than just one ways possible to define a fill type, because it is based on Strategy Pattern.

Parameters:
fillType - type of filling this attribute with data.

getFillType

public final FillType getFillType()
gets the type to fill data to this attribute.

Returns:
type of filling or null

setFillBehaviour

public void setFillBehaviour(FillBehaviour behaviour)
registers the fill behaviour to fill type. This is for convenience. The behaviour could also be registered using the following method:

setFillType(FillType) whereas FillType is replaced by new FillType().setFillBehaviour(behaviour).

Parameters:
behaviour - the type of filling attributes with generated data. Because it is based on Strategy, the algorithm to fill is substitutable.

setUnit

public void setUnit(java.lang.String unit)
sets the unit of an attribute. An unit is a weight or a measure and is defined by a standard. A few examples for units are:

  • length
    • mm, cm, m, km, ...
  • mass
    • g, kg, t, ...
  • time
    • sec, min, h, day, ...
  • temperature
    • C°, F°, K
  • currency
    • Euro, Dollar, Pounds, ...
  • math
    • percent, degree, ...

Of course, not all attributes make use of this setting.

Parameters:
unit - weight or a measurement or null

getUnit

public final java.lang.String getUnit()
gets the unit. That is a weight or a measurement. Notice, not all attributes make use of this setting. In that case, null will be returned!

Returns:
weight or measurement or null

setDistribution

public void setDistribution(ProbabilityDistribution pd)
sets the probability distribution to an attribute. With this setting values are generated or selected by a distribution. For example, if you wanna generate data with and each possible value has the same probability, you go for en even distribution.

Parameters:
pd - probability distribution

getDistribution

public final ProbabilityDistribution getDistribution()
gets the probability distribution attached to this attribute. It specifies how a value is generated or chosen to it.

Returns:
probability distribution or null
